original_title: Sri Lanka’s JKCG says in discussions with authorities over detained Chinese BYDs
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s authorized distributor of BYD vehicles John Keells CG Auto (Pvt) Ltd (JKCG) is “actively engaged” in discussions with the relevant government authorities to clarify an issue with regard motor power, the company said.

Sri Lanka Customs has detained around 1,000 Chinese-made BYD electric vehicles that arrived in the island this month over a motor capacity issue which is used to calculate taxes, official sources have said.
Customs have been declared a motor output of 100 kiloWatts, based on the manufacturers rating where output is limited to 100kW with a reduction is performance.
“We would like to reassure our key stakeholders and the public that… the vehicles in question imported directly from the manufacturer, BYD in China, are 100 kW models,” the JKCG said in a statement.
“These are identical to the models offered for sale in some other international markets such as Singapore,” it said.

“The motor power of these vehicles has been verified through test reports issued by BYD in China and further certified by an independent testing body. As a responsible corporate, JKCG also confirms that all vehicle imports have been conducted in full compliance and applicable local regulations.”

“We remain committed to transparency and are cooperating fully with the authorities to provide all clarifications regarding this matter. JKCG will continue to keep its customers and the other stakeholders informed as the matter progresses.”
BYD sells 100kW models of its Atto 3 model in some markets, where the authorities have allowed the technology.
BYD in Singapore sells an Atto 3 model with a 100kW rated motor to conform to what is called a Category A certificate of entitlement in Singapore, according to the company website.
A lower rated motor means its performance will be lower, and for example may not be able to accelerate as quickly as the one with the higher output motor.
According to the review site OneShift.com the BYD Seal 100kW version takes 10 seconds to accelerate from 0 to 100 (km/h), while the 150kW version does in 5.9 seconds.
Conventional automakers also sell cars the same model car with a range of engine capacities, but the size of the engine can be readily ascertained.
The practice of limiting output of motors in electric cars is new to Sri Lanka and there is uncertainty on what the decision will be.
The excise for a 100 KW motor vehicle is 2.4 million rupees, but this rises to about 5.4 million rupees for a 150 KW vehicle.
If it is determined that the tax applicable for a 150kW car is charged on the 100kW vehicle, a user may have to pay about 4 million rupees extra, an official source said.
Already over 1,000 vehicles have been released to end users.

At a meeting of the Parliament’s Committee on Public Finance earlier this year, some participants raised the matter that the same model car was being charged different taxes based on the motor output declared in the documents submitted by the manufacturer.
The higher taxed car appeared to have been imported as a used car from a market where 150kW BYDs are sold, which has led to the controversy. (Colombo/July 29/2025 – Updated)
